Steps to reproduce
------------------

```powershell
Import-LocalizedData -BaseDirectory $PSScriptRoot -FileName 'mystring.psd' -UICulture 'neutral'
```


**`-UICulture 'neutral'` is only an example.**


Expected behavior
-----------------

load the neutral resources in $PSScriptRoot

comments.author: mklement0
comments.body:
I'm curious what you mean by _neutral strings_.

Wouldn't placing a  `mystring.psd1` file _directly_ in `$PSScriptRoot` do the trick, given that it  will act as the fallback file in case no `'neutral'` (or whatever argument was passed to `-UICulture`) subfolder is found?

You then wouldn't have to bother with the `-UICulture` parameter at all: If a subfolder name for the current culture exists and contains a ` 'mystring.psd1` file, it will get picked up automatically; otherwise, the `$PSScriptRoot` version will be picked up.

comments.author: daxian-dbw
comments.body:
As @lzybkr pointed out in https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/pull/4333#discussion_r129203128, `Import-PowerShellDataFile` should be used in the case that you want to evaluate/import a specific .psd1 file. So I will close this issue as `Resolution-By Design`.
@TravisEz13 please re-open it if you have other concerns.

comments.author: TravisEz13
comments.body: Agreed, filed https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell-Docs/pull/1478 to update the docs to say the two CmdLets are related.

title: Import-LocalizedData should have a parameter to force only using the neutral strings
